entry.title: Re: Implications on not upgrading to SAPGUI 8.00
entry.content:
Hello customer,

Thank you for reaching out to us. 

Regarding your questions:

1.  The SAP GUI 8.00 indeed only supports  BEX 32-bit version. However, it is compatible with SAP GUI 8.00 64 bit version:

SAP Note 3218166 - SAP GUI for Windows: Functional differences of the 64bit version compared to the 32bit version:

  • SAP Business Explorer

    This component will not be supplied as a 64bit version. However, the 32bit version can be combined with a 64bit version of SAP GUI for Windows as long as a 32bit version of Microsoft Office is used. See also SAP Note 3213997. The 64bit installation of SAP GUI for Windows does not contain the 32bit component, you need to get this from a 32bit installation media or from another location. For more information please refer to support component BW-SYS-GUI.

SAP Note 3213997 - BI 7.x tools in 800- General Information & Limitations

2.Considering the support for SAP GUI for Windows 7.70 ended on 9th of April 2024 as per SAP Note 147519.  As of this date, release 7.70 will neither receive functional nor security corrections. Therefore, SAP strongly recommend an upgrade to SAP GUI for Windows 8.00, the only supported version which receives corrections and new features. In addition, SAP GUI 770 Patch level 03 is a very old one (the latest one is PL16, see SAP Note 1053737 - "Expected release dates for SAP GUI for Windows").

Also check SAP Note 3218166 :   

  • No support for 32bit versions of automation components

    The installation of a 64bit version of SAP GUI contains the automation components from SAP Note 2724656 (Logon Control, Table Control, Function Control and BAPI Control) only as 64bit versions. You cannot call these 64bit objects from 32bit processes like Microsoft Excel. If you need to use these components from 32bit processes, you need to keep using the 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows. This is one of the reasons why we generally recommend to take into account the features / bitness of other programs integrating with SAP GUI when deciding for a 64bit or 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows.

 

As per above mentioned information and BEX limitations/availability for SAP GUI 8.00 64 bit, we recommend you to upgrade it to SAP GUI 8.00 32-bit (latest patch level 13).

 

Thank you.

SAP Support.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Hamburg 2025 – Registration Open
entry.content:
We are excited to bring back the SAP Inside Track to Hamburg. Save your ticket via RSVP “Yes” (login required) and join us for a day full of interesting sessions around SAP topics.

Event Details:
Date: September 27, 2025
Registration required: Login and RSVP “Yes” to this event post
Where: SAP Office Hamburg, Tesdorpfstraße 8, 20148 Hamburg

(Preliminary) Agenda

Time

Session

8:30

Registration & Coffee

9:00

Welcome

9:15

How does Cloud Foundry actually work?

10:15

Hands-On-Session: Let's implement together a typescript microservice for BTP with SAP Cloud SDK to talk with any REST API out there

11:15

F*ckUp Diary- minor and major obstacles to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation

12:00

Lunch Break

13:00

Extending S/4HANA Public Cloud with SAP Cloud Application Event Hub

13:45

SAP Architecture Center

14:45

SAP BRIM on S/4HANA

15:30

Coffee Break

16:00

Demystifying SAP Business Suite - Why SAP Cloud Identity Services are key?

16:45

Navigating AI Ethics: Building Trustworthy Futures in Business

17:05

Closing


What is an SAP Inside Track?

An SAP Inside Track is a local grassroots community event where SAP Community members come together to share knowledge about SAP related topics. The event is driven/organized by the community, no cost/entry and very informal: everyone who is interested may take part. Everyone can profit or contribute: act as presenter, take part in discussions, exchange information, realize networking or enjoy the social get-togethers in the evening.

We are looking forward to seeing you at the event.

Your SAP Inside Track Hamburg 2025 organizer team
@Mark_Teichmann @hgoerke @christoph_christophersen @peter_langner @JudithFriedrich

entry.title: Re: Variable Pay Worksheet is not launching
entry.content:
Hi @satnaik18 

Most common is your records not being tied to the bonus plan. Go back to using non-EC/legacy bonus plan eligibility rule where the record is matched to a bonus plan with a 1:1 mapping with the value from the employee history column then retry.

But honestly it could be at least 10 other things which is why we don't go into the rabbit hole of helping people fix these tye of issues.

Please be certified if you are implementing Variable Pay for a customer (because knowing comp does not mean in any way one can implement VarPay) and good luck with your first steps learning it.

All the best,

Xavier

entry.title: Data replication framework (DRF) setup in S4 public cloud to EWM
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are moving a customer from an on-prem Bridge ERP + Boomi integration to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2408 connected to an existing decentral EWM system.

  • Transactional flows (deliveries, warehouse tasks) are already covered by the standard scope items 2VL / 2VM.

  • Master data (Product + Business Partner) still runs through an old Boomi-IDoc flow with prefixes.

  • At go-live the Boomi layer disappears, so we need to set up Data Replication Framework (DRF) from S/4 Cloud to EWM.

Our landscape & assumptions

  • BTP sub-account and Cloud Connector are in place; EWM host/port is exposed.

  • Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0247 will point to that destination.

Question for the community

  1. Is there an official Best Practice or accelerator specifically for DRF master-data replication in Public Cloud (similar to the transactional scope items)?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: SyntaxError: Duplicate property media: already defined
entry.content:
Hi,

I just updated my Android app to BTP SDK for Android version 25.4.5 and now get an error when trying to generate service classes from my metadata.xml. I have the following entity:

<EntityType Name="File" m:HasStream="true" sap:content-version="1"
    sap:label="Datei/Bild">
    <Key>
        <PropertyRef Name="Id" />
    </Key>
    <Property MaxLength="30" Name="Id" Nullable="false" Type="Edm.String"
        sap:creatable="false" sap:filterable="false" sap:label="Datei-ID"
        sap:sortable="false" sap:unicode="false" sap:updatable="false" />
    <Property MaxLength="12" Name="OrderId" Nullable="false" Type="Edm.String"
        sap:creatable="false" sap:filterable="false" sap:label="Auftrag"
        sap:sortable="false" sap:unicode="false" sap:updatable="false" />
    <Property MaxLength="30" Name="DeficitId" Nullable="false" Type="Edm.String"
        sap:creatable="false" sap:filterable="false" sap:label="Mangel-ID"
        sap:sortable="false" sap:unicode="false" sap:updatable="false" />
    <Property MaxLength="128" Name="MimeType" Nullable="false" Type="Edm.String"
        sap:creatable="false" sap:filterable="false" sap:label="MIME-Type"
        sap:sortable="false" sap:unicode="false" sap:updatable="false" />
    <Property MaxLength="255" Name="Comment" Nullable="false" Type="Edm.String"
        sap:creatable="false" sap:filterable="false" sap:label="Bildeschreibung"
        sap:sortable="false" sap:unicode="false" sap:updatable="false" />
    <Property Name="Media" Nullable="false" Type="Edm.Binary" sap:creatable="false"
        sap:filterable="false" sap:label="Binärdaten" sap:sortable="false"
        sap:unicode="false" sap:updatable="false" />
</EntityType>

Which results in the following Code in the product.xs file:

static readonly property media : Property;
get media() { return SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.mediaProperty; }

@metaProperty readonly static property id : Property = SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.getProperty("Id");
@metaProperty readonly static property orderID : Property = SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.getProperty("OrderId");
@metaProperty readonly static property deficitID : Property = SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.getProperty("DeficitId");
@metaProperty readonly static property mimeType : Property = SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.getProperty("MimeType");
@metaProperty readonly static property comment : Property = SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.getProperty("Comment");
@metaProperty readonly static property media : Property = SEKUServiceMetadata.EntityTypes.file.getProperty("Media");

Which gives me the following error:

SyntaxError: Duplicate property media: already defined at: [...]\build\tmp\generateTstDebugODataSources\product.xs:1218:21

Is "Media" as a property name of an entity not allowed anymore with this version of the SDK?

SAP BTP SDK for Android

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP Signavio Process Manager API
entry.content:
I’ve worked with the SAP Signavio Process Manager API before, just enough to know how powerful it is and how confusing it can feel when you're getting started.

So when I was asked to put together a guide, I saw it as an opportunity to write the post I wish I’d had when I first started exploring the API. One that doesn’t just list the endpoints, but explains what to set up, how to authenticate and where to find examples that actually work.

If you're planning to build something with the API or just want to stop clicking through the UI 50 times a day, this guide is for you.

 

What you’ll find in this guide:

  1. Understand When to Use SAP Signavio Process Manager API
  2. How Do I Access the API?
  3. Authentication: Logging In, the API Way
  4. Understand What Endpoints Are Available
  5. Dig Into Specific Requests and Responses
  6. What Happens When Things Go Wrong?
  7. Don’t Forget About Rate Limits
  8. Join the Developer Community

 

Understand When to Use SAP Signavio Process Manager API

The API is designed for users who want to automate tasks, build integrations, or programmatically interact with SAP Signavio Process Manager artifacts like folders, models, and dictionary entries.

Typical use cases include:

  • Creating and updating process diagrams at scale
  • Syncing dictionary items across systems
  • Building custom governance or quality-check pipelines
  • Extracting and analyzing model metadata for reporting

If you're manually clicking through the UI to perform repetitive actions, the API is probably a better fit.

 

First Things First: How Do I Access the API?

Before you can start sending requests to the SAP Signavio Process Manager API, you’ll need the right kind of access. And no, not just “a user account.”

You’ll need:

  • A technical user (Step 1)
  • The API Edition license (Step 2)
  • A proper license assignment in your workspace (Step 3)

Here’s what that actually means in practice.

 

Step 1: Create a technical user (with a reachable email)

If you’re integrating with the API, it’s best to use a dedicated technical user account, not your personal Signavio login and not someone else’s either. The technical user should only have one thing: an API Edition license.

That’s important for two reasons:

  1. It enables headless authentication (no SSO required), which is essential for automation.
  2. It doesn’t consume a paid seat. Regular user licenses are charged, even if you’re just using them for API access.
 
💡 Best practice: Set up one technical user per integration scenario. And use a reachable, role-based email like signavio-integration@yourcompany.com. You’ll need to access this mailbox for password resets and authentication.

For more information, view Setting up Technical Users.

 

Step 2: Get the API Edition license

Already have the API Edition license? Great - skip ahead to Step 3.

Don’t have it yet? No problem. In that case, you’ll need to request one.

Go to SAP for Me and create a support case. Include your Tenant ID in the request. SAP Support will then add the license to your workspace, free of charge. For more information, view Reporting an Issue in the SAP Signavio Support Guide.

 

⚠️ Note: The license is provided at no additional cost. But don’t skip this step. Using a regular license for API access will eat up a paid seat and might result in unintended costs.

For more information, view Getting the License.

 

Step 3: Assign the API Edition license in your workspace

Assigning the API Edition license to technical users works like assigning any other license to a regular user. For more information, view User Accounts.

Once the user is set up, assign only the API Edition license. Don’t add any other license types. Then, make sure the user has the necessary permissions, like reading and writing. These permissions are granted via access rights. Find out more in Manage Access Rights.

You’re now ready to move past setup mode and into action. Let’s get you authenticated.

 

Authentication: Logging In, the API Way

Once your technical user is set up, you're ready to authenticate. At first, the flow might look a bit unusual if you haven’t worked with token-based authentication before, but it's easy to follow once you’ve seen it in action.

Here’s how it works:

 

Step 1: Fetch JWT token

Send a POST request to https://{{host}}/auth/v1/token with your credentials.
You can find the correct host in the SAP Help documentation.

In the request body, provide:

  • The technical user’s email address
  • Their password
  • And your tenant ID (Find the Workspace ID)

You’ll receive two things:

  1. JWT token (in the response body)
  2. JSESSIONID cookie (in the response header)

 

Step 2: Copy JWT token and cookie

Copy JWT token from the response body and JSESSIONID cookie from the response header.

 

Step 3: Call Resource API endpoint and include both JWT token and cookie in your requests

Call a Resource API endpoint (e.g. GET https://{{host}}/spm/v1/search) and:

  • Add x-signavio-id: <JWT token> to your headers
  • Set the cookie JSESSIONID=<sessionId>

You’ll receive an API response:

The token stays valid for 8 hours. After that, you simply repeat the same request to get a fresh one. You can find more details in SAP Help.

 

Understand What Endpoints Are Available

… and What to Do if One Is Missing

The SAP Signavio Process Manager API is structured around resource types, like dictionary entries, folders and diagrams. Each type has its own group of endpoints, all under the /spm/v1 base path.

You can use these endpoints to interact with key objects in SAP Signavio Process Manager. Whether you want to fetch all directories, create a new diagram, or update a dictionary entry, that all happens through this API.

That said, what you're seeing here isn’t the full picture. To explore the complete set of available endpoints, I recommend checking out these official resources:

  1. SAP Business Accelerator Hub - REST API
    A technical API reference in OpenAPI format - an industry standard you can interact with and download.
  2. SAP Help Portal
    Under “Resource APIs”, you’ll find request and response formats, common error codes and practical examples like retrieving models or navigating folders.
  3. GitHub - Postman Collection
    If you're hands-on and want to test things out, the Postman collection is a great place to start.
 
But What If Something’s Missing?

If you find yourself thinking, “Why can’t I do X?”, there’s a place to do something about it.

The SAP Customer Influence Portal is where customers and partners can submit API feature requests. You can also browse ideas from others, vote on them and follow their status. This helps the product team understand what’s most needed and why.

 

💡 Tip: If you hit a limitation, it’s always worth checking whether someone else already raised it. Adding your vote or use case can go a long way in getting it prioritized.

 

Dig Into Specific Requests and Responses

Example: Search API

Once you’ve set up authentication (view earlier chapter), you’re ready to make real API calls. One useful example is searching across models, folders, and dictionary items in your workspace.

Let’s walk through the Search API. You can find more details in both SAP Help and the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

In this example, we want to search for the following SAP Signavio process model via the API:

The search endpoint is a simple GET request to:

👉 https://{{host}}/spm/v1/search

You can find the correct host in the SAP Help documentation.

You can add parameters like q=yourQuery, limit=10, or types=MODEL to filter the results.

Here’s what that looks like in Postman:

The response is a JSON array of matching resources, each including metadata such as name, type, author and revision.

 

What Happens When Things Go Wrong?

Sooner or later, your request might fail. But the good news is: SAP Signavio gives you the tools to troubleshoot.

SAP provides detailed guidance on how to interpret error responses, common issues, and how to fix them. You’ll find the most relevant information in two places:

 

1) SAP Business Accelerator Hub

The Business Hub lists expected responses for each endpoint, including all relevant HTTP error codes:

1. Go to the SAP Signavio Process Manager API in the Business Accelerator Hub.

2. Under “REST API”, select a section, such as Dictionary:

 

3. Navigate to “API Reference” and select an endpoint, such as POST /glossary:

4. Click to expand and scroll down to the Responses section:

2) SAP Help

You’ll find a concise overview of common error codes and what they mean in the Troubleshooting section of the SAP Help documentation.

 

Still stuck?
Open a support ticket under component BPI-SIG-CA-API in SAP for Me. Don’t forget to include your workspace ID / tenant ID, request body and response log to speed up the investigation.

 

Don’t Forget About Rate Limits

Usage of SAP Signavio Process Manager APIs is monitored to ensure that our services are available fairly and reliably.

To prevent overload and ensure consistent performance, the API enforces usage limits. These rate limits define how many requests your application can send within a given time window.

You can find the exact thresholds and guidance in the official SAP Help documentation.

 

Join the Developer Community

Have a question? Built something cool? Share it!

The SAP Signavio developer community is a growing space where users share what they’ve built, ask questions and exchange best practices. Whether you're stuck on a request, looking for inspiration, or want to showcase your latest integration, this is the place to be.

🧠 Make sure to check out our Q&A and blog posts for more ideas and insights.

 

Thanks for reading! 🎉

I hope this guide gave you a solid foundation to start building and maybe even sparked some ideas along the way.

I'm working on a planning process in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) that distributes costs based on the number of units per cost center (CECO).

Here’s the logic I’ve implemented:

  • I have a driver table where I input the distribution percentage by channel (e.g., Retail, Wholesale, E-commerce).

 

  • That percentage is then distributed proportionally based on the number of units per CECO.

The issue I’m facing is that if a CECO has no units reported, its portion of the percentage should be redistributed among the remaining CECOs that do have units.

Has anyone implemented a similar logic in a Data Action or Advanced Script in SAC Planning?
Thanks in advance!

entry.title: ODBC driver for ABAP examples on GitHub
entry.content:
Are you searching for practical examples of using the ODBC driver for ABAP in popular programming languages? Look no further—our GitHub repository has got you covered: ODBC Driver for ABAP Examples.

Currently, the repository features examples for the following languages:

  • C++
  • NodeJS
  • PowerShell
  • Python
  • Rust

These examples utilize a consistent set of ABAP objects, which are described in the repository. The example objects are also shipped with ABAP systems as part of the package SABP_DBC2ABAP_TEST.
We also provide a configuration template for unixodbc, our preferred driver manager for unix platforms.

Our examples not only demonstrate the capabilities of the ODBC driver for ABAP but also guide you on integrating it with the ODBC libraries specific to each language. Additionally, we aim to point out important limitations for each language.

We recognize the value of community contributions, and your input is invaluable. If there's a particular language or feature you think should be included, don’t hesitate to let us know. You can create an issue on GitHub, or, even better, contribute by submitting a pull request with your own example.

entry.title: Common set-up issues of Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
This Blog continues my previous setup blog post - Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - A Comprehensive Setup Guide. 

Note: The below are general findings. For detailed analysis of issues, we recommend checking the SAP Help Portal or working with SAP Incidents. 

You can find the list of the most common issues here:

  1. Joule is not answering as expected, but only giving instructions on how to access information
  2. Joule is not greeting you with your name or showing a blank screen
  3. Joule responds with “I’m having trouble connecting.”

 

1.      Joule is not answering as expected, but only giving instructions on how to access information

Reason: This is often a sign that the actual logged-on user has insufficient roles assigned or that the assigned roles are not known to Joule.

 

Fix: Joule requires access to the actual backend system and needs to know about assigned S/4HANA user roles to pre-select appropriate capabilities.

Some Joule capabilities are linked to Semantic Objects and Actions, so only users with access to those Semantic Objects will also be able to access them via Joule. Typically, when the respective Fiori app is accessible to the user, this will also grant access via Joule. However, it’s important that user/role assignments are replicated to Workzone and, therefore, known to Joule.

Figure 1: The picture on the left shows the expected response, while the right picture shows that Joule does a fallback citing user assistance resources.

When Joule does not find the respective role assigned to a user, it will resort to informational capabilities, such as citing out-of-help documentation.

a. Check if there is a capability available in the catalog that allows Joule to actually access data from a backend, see the help documentation

b. Find the required Semantic Objects and Actions for each Joule Capability in the SAP Note 3523238 attached spreadsheet

c. Check if your SAP S/4HANA Cloud version supports that capability (see column F)

Note: In case of a release upgrade of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system, you must trigger an update of Joule’s capability catalog. To do so in your SAP BTP Global Account, go to Formations, find the relevant Joule formation, and Exclude and afterwards Include your S/4HANA Private Cloud system.

d. Check if the respective Fiori app is included within your exposed CDM content.

In transaction /UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE go to “Preview Content”, ensure that the respective user role has the Fiori App ID linked

Fiori apps, their App IDs, and Semantic Objects and Actions can be found in the Fiori Apps Library.

 

Transactions /n/ui2/flia or /n/UI2/FLPCM_CUST allows to find Roles for a specific Semantic Object:

e. Go to your SAP Build Work Zone Admin -> Channel Manager and check if the CDM content was properly read from S/4HANA. Note the “Report” only shows newly created artifacts.

In case of errors, click “edit” to find the name of the “Design Time” destination. Within your BTP Cockpit check you can do a Connection test of the destination:

 

Further help:

https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/troubleshooting-e69b6f5d31a542c6a5f87c8b45c1d427

Besides also it is also recommended to schedule a job to regularly update content: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/a7b390faab1140c087b8926571e942b7/a6e718dcfe4f47e5adc71078bb35ec74.html?version=202110.000

 

f.  Go to your SAP Build Work Zone Admin -> Settings -> SAP Identity Provisioning and check if your user has the necessary roles assigned. These can also be customer-specific roles; it is important that the standard Fiori applications with their Semantic Objects (see column D above) are included within those roles.

PS: SAP Build Work Zone also offers an API for advanced scenarios; you can find details here.

If no roles are listed, check the provisioning jobs in Cloud Identity services – Identity Provisioning service (IPS) for errors or filter conditions.

 

g. Check if the necessary OData API was activated in your system 

 

2. Joule is not greeting you with your name or showing a blank screen

Issue: When Joule is not greeting you with your name, it is an indication that the wrong identity is used and not mapped to the identity in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Fix: Joule requires a global user identity within all connected systems to act on behalf of the business user. Therefore, Joule uses an identity stored locally within SAP Cloud Identity services (Identity Directory). It is important that user attributes (first name, last name, email, global user ID) are properly mapped from potential third-party identity providers to a local identity in SAP Cloud Identity services, and the same are forwarded to Joule during authentication.

 

  • Ensure that your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system is configured to use the very same SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant for authentication as your Joule instance.
  • Ensure that the top-level domain (e.g., cloud.sap or ondemand.com) is set-up consistent within your landscape.

In SAP S/4HANA, check transaction SAML2 -> Trusted Providers

 

In BTP Cockpit -> your Joule subaccount -> Trust Configuration -> check the “Domain” selection:

  • Ensure that the global user id is distributed across your complete landscape

In transaction SU01 -> open the respective business users -> click “Goto” -> click “External user id (UID)” and validate that the same ID is maintained as within SAP Cloud Identity Services, Identity Directory (“Global User ID”).

See also: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity/system-integration-guide/global-user-id-in-integration-scenarios?locale=en-US

 

3. Joule responds with “I’m having trouble connecting.”

Issue: When Joule responds, “I’m having trouble connecting. Please make sure you are online and can access your SAP system,” this indicates that Joule tried to access the backend but was not able to access it.

Fix: Often, the principal propagation between Joule, BTP Destination, SAP Cloud Connector, WebDispatcher, ICM, and the API within the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition system is broken.

You can trace Joule’s interactions for a specific user by starting an HTTP Payload trace in transaction /n/IWDFND/TRACES

 

A very good troubleshooting guide can be found here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/appservices/3361376259.html

Other helpful resources:

https://github.com/SAP-archive/cloud-platform-connectivity-principal-propagation/blob/master/exercises/B2/README.md

https://help.sap.com/doc/si/1.0/en-US/attachments/3362959224/WebDispatcherSSLCertificateForwarding_V3.pdf

 

Cheers, 

Happy Learning. 

Credits and Co-Written with RIG Team - @mathias Rup

entry.title: Complete your Advanced Shipping & Receiving (ASR) process with a PGI event
entry.content:
A common requirement in TM-EWM projects is the need to update the execution status or report an event on freight orders after the PGI. When configuring the Advanced Shipping & Receiving process, it is possible to specify the event that should be reported after the goods movement in the outbound processes.

This makes it possible to make your process more agile and cohesive, and to provide feedback to your freight order with all the necessary information, aiming to have a single point of reference for the process progress.

For this purpose, SAP provides the TM Save Strategy called PGI_REP_EV shown in the print below, which must be configured in the freight orders relevant to the ASR process:

After the entire process is executed in the ASR, our freight order will have these events, where the next step is the execution of the PGI and then the departure from door, which are executed in the Load or Unload Freight Orders app. Without the above configuration, only during the "departure from door" step is an event reported, which in this case is "Departure From Door".

This way we go to the "Load or unload Freight Orders" App and perform the PGI:

And this way, the "Checkout" event is reported. Furthermore, according to the Event Profile configured for this Freight order, the "Departure From Door" event is set as mandatory and will therefore also be reported.

Therefore, it will not be necessary to run this departure process on the monitor:

An important point is that it's possible to configure the event that will be reported for this strategy. As mentioned above, the reported event was "Checkout". This event was determined through a process controller parameter linked to the method and the standard strategy. However, the class is prepared to be configured with a custom strategy (ZPGI_REP_E) and a custom parameter (ZEVENT_CODE), so you can determine which event will be reported via configuration:

To do this:

  • Create your own strategy according to the name described in the code and include the same method as the standard strategy
  • Create the parameter also with the custom name described
  • And then assign the event code to the parameter and strategy in this last menu of the process controller configuration:

Margit

entry.title: Re: Require help with SAP Build Process Automation and SA...
entry.content:
The full list of setup guides can be found in KBA 3636966 - Integrating SAP Cloud ALM and SAP Build Process Automation.

SAP Cloud ALM currently only supports monitoring of SAP Build Process Automation in 2 scenarios, Health Monitoring and Job & Automation Monitoring. The setup guide can be found here.

If you must transport SAP Build Process Automation, this can be achieved using Multitarget Applications (MTAs) and integrating the managing Cloud Transport Management Service instance with SAP Cloud ALM, as per this guide.

entry.title: Are we able to auto-renew custom SSL certificates?
entry.content:
Over the next 5 years, the lifetime of SSL/TLS certificates is decreasing from currently 398 days to 200 days in 2026 to eventually 47 days in 2029 - see https://www.sectigo.com/47-day-ssl-guide
Therefore, is there tools to auto-renew custom certificates in SAP Commerce Cloud, similar to the out of the box ones ? If not, will there be this function in the future?

Additionally, can custom endpoints be added to OOTB certificates?

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Are we able to auto-renew custom SSL certificates?
entry.content:
1. We don't have auto-renewal of custom certificates in commerce cloud, even if they're Let's Encrypt certificates and currently, there is no discussion of bringing the feature into place. Auto-renewal is only available for OOTB certificates. Please see this help page - https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_CLOUD_PUBLIC_CLOUD/0fa6bcf4736c46f78c248512391eb467/e320ae243ca94c1ab7d4391c67abeab9.html?locale=en-US#loioeebd15e506c6450fa0196569ecb2a6a0.
  2. Currently there is no provision of adding custom endpoints to OOTB certificates. Customers having custom endpoints, use custom certificates which they have to renew on their own.

entry.title: Homogeneous System Copy to create new server using SWPM - Clarification on manual restore steps
entry.content:
Hi,

We need to build a parallel environment and the approach is to do a system copy using SWPM.

I have reached the point in SWPM where it is prompting as follows:

Software Provisioning Manager now stops the installation. Proceed as follows:

  1. Make sure you have selected: CONTROL.SQL file created with OraBRCopy tool
  2. Restore the Oracle backup as described in the system copy guide.
  3. Proceed with the database instance installation by choosing 'OK' in this dialog box.

However, the SystemCopy71X_ux_abap System Copy guide (section 5.1.2.4) seems to be missing information or is not clear on the next steps.

It seems to imply that a brrestore command is required but doesn't list the command.

It does, however list a brrecover command (in relation to Oracle TDE).

Based on answers to a previous post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/homogeneous-system-copy-to-new-server-windows-oracle/qaq-p/617025 

my understanding is that I just need to do the following:

brrestore to copy in the database files.

Then Click "OK" back on the SWPM screen and this will take care of brrecover and related tasks. 

Does this sound correct?

I have another question on which mode (-m) I should choose for the brrestore command.

Does it need to be set to "-m full" so that we copy over the mirrlog origlog files? If that's the case, then we would need to delete the control files that were brought over before continuing with SWPM. 

Running brrestore with just "-m all" won't bring the mirrlog files over.

Any advice would be much appreciated. 

Ray

entry.title: What's New in 2508 - Release Navigator for Spend Management
entry.content:
We're thrilled to announce the upcoming innovations for our 2508 Release! Our dedicated team has been working tirelessly to ensure you stay ahead with the latest enhancements.

Over the coming months, we'll be revamping and enriching our related content to mirror the newest advancements. Currently users can still access Business Network via the Release Navigator for Spend Management, you will be re-directed to the Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management. As this journey continues, SAP Business Network content will begin to migrate from Spend Management communications to Supply Chain Management communications and portals! Dive into the 2508 release details below. 

Here are feature Highlights for the 2508 release for SAP Ariba and SAP Business Network. Make sure to read through the blogs to learn more about these features and ensure you are properly prepared for these updates.

SAP Ariba:

  • Joule in SAP Ariba Applications including features: GUIDEB-1163, SLP-2258, SOURCE-2725
  • FRM-809: WalkMe Available in SAP Ariba Products
  • ARBCATA-463: Ability to Set an Initiative as Obsolete in SAP Ariba Category Management
  • GUIDEB-915: Asset Management in Guided Buying
  • SOURCE-2260: Enhancement to Guided Sourcing

SAP Business Network:

  • BNCAT-3708: Trading Partner Search for Suppliers
  • APIN-3306: Enhancements to Relationship Management User Interface
  • NS-34429: Enhanced Notification Option for Buyers

FRM-809: WalkMe Available in SAP Ariba Products

The WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform is now integrated with SAP Ariba products. Users can take advantage of easy-to-understand guidance powered by WalkMe.

WalkMe is an AI-powered solution that enables teams to create guidance and automation in the flow of work, while giving business and technology leaders insights into how people are using the software and where users can be more self-sufficient. This enables organizations to accelerate user adoption of technology, boost productivity, and maximize the value of enterprise software investments.

WalkMe is available in the following SAP Ariba capabilities and products:

  • Guided sourcing
  • Guided buying
  • SAP Ariba Invoice Management
  • SAP Ariba Contracts
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Risk

WalkMe comes with standard content from SAP Ariba.

You can add custom content tailored for your organization by first purchasing WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba Solutions and creating your own WalkMe content.

 

For more information about WalkMe for SAP Ariba check out the What’s New Viewer Documentation.

 

 

Follow the Spend Management and Business Network and ReadinessS@Scale community tags, and Ryan Russman to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

The 2508 release will incorporate release content updates only. With the migration of SAP Business Network to Supply Chain Management, the Release Navigator for Spend Management will continue to publish content updates but may delay UX updates to help minimize disruption to customers and partners.

Support.SAP.com – Release Ready page 

SAP Activate – Roadmap Viewer  

SAP Enterprise Support Value Map - SAP Enterprise Support Value Map for Spend Management and Business Network

Making Your Impact

At SAP, we greatly appreciate your input and suggestions. You are invited to submit feedback and suggest topics to be covered through our Topic Request & Feedback Survey. This survey provides you with an opportunity to provide insights on your experience with the release navigator for Spend Management and Business Network, as well as suggestions on how we can further enhance your release experience. Additionally, we encourage you to share your feedback, thoughts, or questions in the comment section below.

entry.title: Re: Source in Job info updating as Performance management...
entry.content:
Hi - this was an intentional change with the 1H release but unfortunately it wasn't documented well enough. No, it cannot be disabled whilst the business rule is in place. The full process is as follows:

  1. A Job Info change is saved
  2. An onPostSave triggers the "Initiate PM Form" event
  3. Performance Management generates the form
  4. Performance Management updates the Job Info record that triggered the event with the form-id of the form just generated

Step #4 was happening just the same before the 1H release, but it would wipe out the "Source" information for this record in the History UI, which was not very transparent. Now with 1H, instead of no source at all, the History UI displays "Performance Management" as the source of the last update to this record.

I am not sure what exactly you mean when you say "we are unable to view the hire record" because if the form was generated for a hire record, then that's still a hire record afterwards. It was created through e.g. "Add New Employee" or an import/Odata upsert, and it was then modified by Performance Management - and both of these steps can be seen in audit reports as well.

entry.title: Re: Choosing the Right Authorization Method in SAP Integr...
entry.content:
Hi Stefan

1. This is old topic actually, you can check this thread:
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/how-to-deactivate-or-disable-client-id-and-client-secret-for-basic/qaq-p/12800067

Unfortunatelly there is no option to disable Basic auth using client id & client secret.

Alternative is to use client certificate as a medium to fetch Access token or Client certificate itself (then no OAuth) either as part of BTP service key (RBAC) or directly in iflow.

You can also consider APIM if already in use in your organisation. Then you can explicitly create one API endpoint to generate Access Token and another one - actual API call to CI iflow with Token verification. Then you are provisioning safe access to your CI iflow only via OAuth and not Basic Auth.

2. Yes, sometimes also .pfx is needed which can be generated from .pem and .key

3. for outbound web services (consumer proxy with manual logical port) there is OAuth as authentication option.
I can see it on my S4H on premise system.
Hovewer there are some SAP notes telling that for older version Software package needs to be installed:
https://me.sap.com/notes/0003410682
https://me.sap.com/notes/3359819
https://me.sap.com/notes/0003145440

for inbound web services (service definition) there is no OAuth possibility:
https://me.sap.com/notes/0003507598

entry.title: Re: Create SAP S/4HANA External GL Account Hierarchy within SAP Datasphere using standard CDS Views
entry.content:
Hi @Sefan_Linders. I checked and found the values are set to null but the issue is the total ACDOCU amount (-54,826,587.69) corresponding to all GLs is getting assigned to each hierarchy node, even if there are no GL accounts or transactions associated with that node.

Additionally, for nodes that do have child nodes, this amount is also being added on top of the sum of all their child nodes. So, we’re essentially seeing a double counting effect — the total amount is being shown at every level and also accumulated again through the hierarchy.

Your guidance here would be highly helpful

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA configuration for SAC pull of plan data
entry.content:
This post deals with the SAP S/4HANA app “Manage Financial Plan Data Jobs - for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration” (in the following referred to as “manage” app) where mandatory configuration settings for pulling plan data from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) into SAP S/4HANA tables like ACDOCP or FINSSKF are defined. These configuration settings are prerequisite for the app “Schedule Financial Plan Data Jobs for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration“ to execute a financial plan data job (for data replication). The integration using these two apps is available in SAP S/4HANA Public and Private Cloud Edition.

The goal is to provide guidance on the necessary configuration settings in this manage app and show example configurations based on SAC content for different use cases.

It is recommended to bookmark this post, as we plan to enhance it with further recommendations and configuration settings.

Before creating a configuration in this manage app, a tenant ID (with communication details) must be created first which is explained in the following online help:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1cbcff7ccd35405ab445b223c1ab1588/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/48f4b4785b8e45938ac44a67be8032d9/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US

This post is based on the following SAC content for Integrated Financial Planning with possible plan data replications into S/4HANA tables but apply to other (customer specific) SAC models writing into these S/4HANA tables as well.

To simplify, we assume that depreciations are copied from the SAC model CAPEX to model OPEX and asset values ​​from the SAC model CAPEX to model Financial Statement Planning. So we only deal with configuration entries for plan data related to OPEX, Sales and Profitability Planning and Financial Statement. CO2 values ​​are also ignored (might be addressed in a later version of this post).

We start with functional and technical basics, continue with general recommendations and finally show some example configurations.

Functional Basics

For replication of plan data related to the three IFP models OPEX, Profitability and Financial Statement into SAP S/4HANA, the following SAC modeling details must be considered:

  • In contrast to Profitability and Financial Statement, only OPEX has a dimension for the debit/credit indicator to represent cost charges and discharges. However, for profitability and financial statement data, the debit/credit indicator ‘D’ is added by default when writing into table ACDOCP. The debit/credit indicator becomes part of the plan data scope explained below.
  • When transferring sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability, the same account used to post into Profitability is used to credit records in OPEX. However, in contrast to OPEX, product and plant information is added to these costs in Profitability.
  • The starting point for financial statement planning is a copy of actual data from the previous year’s financial statement. Then plan data from OPEX and Profitability are copied into Financial Statement, i.e. these copy processes do NOT result in corresponding credit records on the sender side.
  • The IFP content in SAC offers two possible sources for bringing a profit and loss statement into table ACDOCP:
    • Option 1: The model Financial Statement serves as the source to ensure a complete P&L statement. Since the copy of actual data is used as a starting point, the data can contain recurring extraordinary revenues and costs like the dissolution of accruals etc. 
    • Option 2: The two models OPEX and Profitability serve as the source. Here special attention is required for the account(s) used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability (more on this later). In contrast to Option 1, this option has only operating costs and revenues.

Technical Basics

It is important to understand that contrary to table ACDOCA, table ACDOCP represents a multidimensional view. Therefore, the key fields of table ACDOCP consist of purely technical fields. This makes it necessary to specify a so-called aggregation level and plan data scope when writing data into table ACDOCP. These are explained below (among other technical terms for the Manage app).

  1. Aggregation level
    The aggregation level determines the fields of the records for which plan data is transferred into SAP S/4HANA. In the following mapping view of the configuration for the SAC plan data pull, the listed SAP S/4HANA fields are automatically translated into this aggregation level:
    As you can see in the last four columns of the screenshot above, it does not matter for the derivation of the aggregation level whether the field is mapped 1:1 from SAC, derived from an attribute (of an SAC dimension), or defined as a fixed value.
  2. Plan Data Scope
    The plan data scope influences which existing data records in table ACDOCP are replaced by the new plan data. Therefore, based on the fields marked “In Scope” (i.e. plan data scope) and their corresponding values from the plan data (to be written into ACDOCP), a data set is identified in the (multidimensional) table ACDOCP.
    It is important to understand that for the derivation of this “data set” not only the existing value combinations from the fields marked as “In Scope” are used, but also cross-combinations of these field values (see example 3 below).
    The following three scenarios show how new plan data with the respective plan data scope setting overwrites existing data in table ACDOCP.
    The more fields are added to the plan data scope, the fewer existing records can be overwritten with the new data, and thus the impacted data section is smaller (see example 2). This is also the reason why some fields such as the planning category or time-related fields like LedgerFiscalYear or FiscalYearPeriod are mandatory in the plan data scope, so that more data than desired is not accidentally overwritten when writing plan data into ACDOCP.
    In the configuration of the manage application, the plan data scope is defined in following highlighted column of the mapping view.
  3. Interaction between update mode and plan data scope
    Because the update mode for reading the relevant plan data records in SAC is a full update, SAC data is always written as a “whole” into table ACDOCP. Therefore, for cost-center-related costs, for example, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope (to replace the existing cost-center-related accounts and periods with the new plan data). Another example are project-related costs, where the WBSElement, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope. This ensures that the new plan data from SAC replaces the existing data in ACDOCP correctly.
  4. Account selection
    In the Filter Settings section of a configuration ID in the Manage app, meaningful data selections via G/L accounts are limited, as hierarchy nodes are not supported for the account field. For example, selecting primary accounts, cost accounts or balance sheet accounts using hierarchy nodes is not supported. Unfortunately, this type of selection is only possible via flat account selection, where the relevant accounts are then listed.
  5. Lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP
    Given that the lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP is based on the SAP S/4HANA fields PlanningCategory, ControllingArea, CompanyCode and LedgerFiscalYear, simultaneously running pull jobs into the same planning category can lock each other (for overlapping controlling areas, company code and fiscal year). However, in SAP S/4HANA no locks can occur if simultaneous pull jobs are writing into different planning categories. Therefore this should be considered when using multiple configuration IDs.

General configuration-specific recommendations

After clarifying some functional and technical basics, let’s look at the following recommendations for the configuration:

  • In general, overlapping plan data across different configurations which are written into the same planning category inevitably leads to inconsistent data when running the financial plan data jobs for the respective configuration IDs (due to the conflict with the plan data scope and subsequent mutual overwriting). An example of this is the configuration for (total) expenses and another configuration specifically for project-related expenses (subset of total expenses). Therefore, it is important to avoid such cases by defining different plan categories in the mapping section for the SAP S/4HANA field PlanningCategory.
  • Plan data from the IFP model Financial Statement must always kept in a separate planning category (in contrast to plan data from the IFP models OPEX and Sales & Profitability) to avoid inconsistencies due to duplicate figures. The reason is that OPEX und Sales & Profitability data is copied into the SAC model Financial Statement without crediting on the sender side.
  • In the case of writing OPEX and Profitability data into one planning category (for an alternative P&L report in SAP S/4HANA), having the field GLAccount as an additional “In Scope” field helps differentiate the two data sets (to avoid mutual overwrite), if OPEX and Sales & Profitability use different GL accounts. However, if, for example, a single GL account is used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Sales and Profitability, this approach no longer ensures disjoint data, and the plan data scope must be expanded. If, as shown in the following example, OPEX consists only of cost center data (and is marked as “In Scope”), and all Sales & Profitability data has a Plant, Sold Material and Customer allocation (and is marked as “In Scope”), disjoint data is ensured as well (without mutual overwrite):
  • A mapping of profit center and functional area values for a given configuration ID in the view ”Mapping of Financial Plan Data” ​​(to transfer both fields from SAC) is optional for OPEX and Profitability, since both would be automatically derived in the ACDOCP write interface if missing. If, however, Profit Center and Functional Area are mapped (and thus transferred from SAC), the correct profit center and functional area assignment is checked in SAP S/4HANA before writing plan data into table ACDOCP.  If this consistency check fails because, for example, the derived account assignment type returns a different profit center, an error message appears and the data transfer is aborted. Therefore, when mapping the functional area and/or profit center, ensure that the master data in SAP Analytics Cloud is up to date.
  • When using the SAP-delivered planning categories BUDGET01, BUDGET02 and BUDGET03 when writing into table ACDOCP,  the following default value for Budget Consistency Check (screenshot taken from SSCUI ID 102822) requires that additional (plan data scope) requirements be taken into account:For example, for project budget (planning category BUDGET01), plan data scope must NOT be active for WBSElement, FiscalPeriod, FiscalYearPeriod and CompanyCode. For the cost center budget (planning category BUDGET02), plan data scope must NOT be active for FiscalPeriod and FiscalYearPeriod.
  • Balance sheet data as part of financial statement planning requires a balance carry-forward logic to ensure that opening balance and balance sheet movements within a fiscal year are correctly replicated from SAC into table ACDOCP. Like in the SAC Export API, this requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA global field BalanceFlowType (see in below file configuration ID 30001).
  • Costs split into fixed and variable costs in SAC can also be replicated and stored in table ACDOCP, which requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA field FixedVariableType. In this case, the data records split into fixed and variable are merged into one data record on the SAP S/4HANA side, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written into the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).

Example Configurations

Finally, the file in the following URL shows predefined configuration settings to give an idea of how to configure specific content in the mapping and filter section: https://d.dam.sap.com/a/MVuKTRq?rc=10&doi=SAP1225684

The first example (configuration ID 10001) from the file for OPEX-related plan data on cost centers and projects, including value-based allocations, is explained based on screenshots from the manage app:

Mapping of Financial Plan Data

  • For the SAC measure AMOUNT on the SAP S/4HANA side, the measure AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency is used (and the currency derived from a property of the company code), assuming the company code currency in SAC plan data.
  • The displayed plan data scope contains the mandatory plan data scope fields PlanningCategory, CompanyCode and FiscalYearPeriod (or LedgerFiscalYear) and is sufficient if there is no other overlapping configuration ID writing into the same planning category.
  • As described, ProfitCenter and FunctionalArea are not included, as this proposal relies on the derivation rules in SAP S/4HANA to derive the two fields in the background when writing plan data into table ACDOCP.
  • Including the source field FixedVariableType ensures that when writing into table ACDOCP the plan data is reformatted accordingly, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written to the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).
  • In the example, the SAP Planning category PLN is used. Likewise, another category can be selected, which is maintained in SAP S/4HANA with Application Type “Periodic Planning & Consolidation” and Category Usage “NO specific usage” (in SSCUI 101970, Maintain Category for Planning).

Filter Settings for Financial Plan Data

  • The mandatory single value filter for the source field Version is maintained here. In the IFP content, the version Plan is used by default and may need to be adjusted if it differs in the custom data model.
  • It should also be filtered by planning period to select the plan data to the respective planning year.
  • In this example, further filter settings are not necessary because, on the one hand, this configuration is for OPEX-related plan data including cost centers and projects and only the AMOUNT measure is mapped. Other measures are excluded (like measures related to allocation weights ).

entry.title: Onboarding of SAP BTP Build Work Zone Service: Advanced edition
entry.content:
Do you know while planning to onboard the SAP BTP Build Work Zone Service, what is the checklist, onboarding steps needs to be follow?

SAP Build Work Zone is released with Standard and advanced edition.

We are planning to onboard the SAP Build Work Zone advanced edition.

Let’s discuss the high level.

Onboarding steps (disclaimer: It does depend on scenario to scenario)

S.No

Task

1

Create BTP Subaccount

2

Assign quotas & entitlements

3

Enable Build Work Zone service (Through Booster run)

4

Configure IAS & Trust

5

Setup XSUAA & Destinations

6

Create Roles and Role Collections

7

Add Business Content (Fiori, etc.)

8

Customize UI

 

Create BTP Subaccount:

Enable Cloud Foundry:

Trust configuration:

Add Domain and parameter : Review and complete.

Trust configuration completed

Validate the status of Trust configuration

Once you complete S.  No 1 & 2, then let’s run the Booster:

The SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition booster assists you by performing configuration steps automatically in your subaccount.

To run the booster:

  1. In the SAP BTP cockpit, use the breadcrumbs to access your global account.
  2. In the side menu, open the Boosters screen and click the Get Started with SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition tile.
  3. SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition contains integration with SAP Build Process Automation service. SAP Build Process Automation is a citizen developer solution to adapt, improve, and innovate business processes with no-code workflow management and robotic process automation capabilities. If you are not planning to use SAP Build Process Automation, you can remove the service when you run the booster.

Confirm to run the Booster

Follow all the steps and complete the Build Work Zone onboarding.

Delete all, apart from Advanced edition

Onboarding setup is running

Congratulations, Booster executed successfully.

Navigate to BTP Subaccount and verify the service.

Manual execution of the Booster: If needed.

If you encounter technical issues in running the booster, here are the steps that the booster performs for you:

In the SAP BTP cockpit, select a subaccount and perform the following configuration steps:

  1. In the Overview screen, enable Cloud Foundry and create an org and a space.
  2. In the Entitlements screen, assign entitlements to all the services that are listed in the Components table.
  3. In the Services  Instances and Subscriptions screen, subscribe and create service instances to the service plans that are listed in the Service plan configuration table.
  4. Create a destination to the content repository.

Run the Configurator

Launch the Configurator Wizard

After completing all previous steps, follow the configurator wizard to complete the onboarding process. You can access the configurator directly from the booster, or you can access it from the Site Manager as follows:

  • In the SAP BTP cockpit, Services  Instances and Subscriptions, click the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition link in the Subscriptions table to access the application.
  • Open the Configurator screen from the left-side menu.

Go to Site Manager: Go to Settings

Enable Identity Authentification

Now run the configurator

Select the default or custom domain as per your scenario

 

Before triggering the setup, open the Destinations in SAP BTP Cockpit and download the trust

Now trigger the setup

Environment Setup completed, move to next step

Step 3: Configure the IAS, IPS to enable user authentication and user provisioning.

Switch to SAP Cloud Identity Service - Identity Authentication:

This step is only applicable to subscriptions created before March 20th, 2025. If you created a subscription after this date, your subaccount is already connected directly to Identity Authentication and you can skip this step.

Connect Your Subaccount to Identity Provisioning:

Prerequisites

  • The integration with the Identity Provisioning service supports only one active Identity Authentication tenant. Before you start the configuration, open the cockpit, Security  Trust Configuration, and verify that you have only one active Identity Authentication trust configuration in the list. The default IdP, sap.default, is not relevant to the flow and can be ignored for this requirement. After the connection is formed, you can configure additional active IdPs.
  • If you already have an active Identity Authentication tenant, you are required to reconnect it to the Identity Provisioning service after you've modified it.

Connector for User and Group Provisioning

Open the Settings screen from the left-side menu.

Go to the Identity Provisioning tab, and click the Connect button.

If your subaccount is not yet connected to the Identity Provisioning service, a new tenant will be created for your subaccount, and it will include the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition connector. In addition, a connection will be created between the Identity Authentication service and the Identity Provisioning service.

If your subaccount already has an Identity Provisioning tenant connected to the Identity Authentication service, clicking the connect button will expand the scope of the tenant to include the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition connector.

At this point, the connector is created with default values. In the next step of the onboarding, when you run the configurator, you will have to configure specific values.

SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition is also available as a bundle connector.

 

Click Assertion Attribute and add Groups form the list must start with an upper case

Add the Groups

Now add Default attributes : Add groups must start with upper case

Make sure you are selecting the correct value

Create Basic  WZ Groups with reference help portal

Do the same

Create an application in IAS: Go to application & resource application and open the SAML 2.0 configuration

Create Application

In next step upload the trust file and move to configure

Now enable the permission for Administrator

Add the secret client ID

Configure the Identity Provisioning service: Source and Target systems

Let’s do for Source system

Add mandatory properties

Remember to add the URL

Now setup Build Work Zone as Target

Add mandatory properties

Copy default transformation depending on API version

Run provisioning job

Check the job status

Congratulation job was able to read and create the users.

Now go to Site manager again and run the Configurator from below step.

 

Congratulations you have completed the onboarding process

Access the Build Work Zone

Note* This blog has not included all the steps screenshot, only major one added.

Thank you.

Please do share your thought.

 

Reference : https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-advanced-edition/sap-build-work-zone-advanced-edition/what-is-sap-build-work-zone-advanced-edition

entry.content:

This is reg. the error "Arrival date/time is earlier than Departure date/time" on the freight unit, which is not allowing to plan the freight unit.

this is happening when ATP confirms the order with backward scheduled with Route as 0 days transit. in this case, even though planned goods issue on same day but time will be > 00:00, but Arrival date is set to "00:00", which is causing the error "Departure of stage 10 must not be after arrival" while planning the freight unit.

Nagender.

entry.title: Re: Bulk UserID change in LMS
entry.content: At the system backend level, there’s a threshold that allows a maximum of 5,000 user merges within a 30-day period. To request an increase in this limit, a case with Support must be submitted for review (Considerations Before Bulk Merging Users Through Import).
